title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness when hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" includes a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not apply subsection (a) to wages paid to qualified individuals for services performed during a specific period. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for qualified employers hiring individuals in 2010, allowing them to not apply subsection (a) to wages paid for services performed during a specific period. Qualified employers are defined as any employer other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for qualified employers hiring individuals in 2010. A qualified individual is defined as someone who starts employment with a qualified employer after February 3, 2010, and before January 1, 2011, and certifies that they have not worked for more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting the new job. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for qualified employers hiring individuals in 2010. A qualified individual must not have worked more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting the new job and must not be replacing another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause. Qualified employers can elect to not apply this subsection. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to apply the special exemption for hiring individuals in 2010. The exemption excludes wages paid to qualified individuals for a 1-year period from the hiring date. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to apply the special exemption for hiring individuals in 2010, excluding wages paid to qualified individuals for a 1-year period from the hiring date. Amounts are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to apply the special exemption for hiring individuals in 2010. Amounts appropriated will be transferred from the general fund to offset revenue reductions. The amendments made by this section apply to wages paid after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit for taxable years after the enactment of the Act will increase by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets certain criteria. A retained worker is a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer during the taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that a retained worker is someone employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling at least 80 percent of the first 26 weeks.
